DOC.HEAD: Sale of Psychiatric Division Falls Through
DOC.TEXT: Hospital Corp. of America has stopped a plan to sell its psychiatric hospital division to the unit's employees because financing could not be obtained, the company said. The sale of HCA Psychiatric Co. and its 53 hospitals was to have been completed by the end of the year. No other offers are before the company, said Victor L. Campbell, vice president of corporate relations. The $1.23 billion sale was to have been financed through an employee stock ownership plan, with HCA retaining a 10 percent to 30 percent stake in the new company. ``We've been working on this since the summer and there have been a multitude of things that have taken place, primarily in the financial markets,'' Campbell said Tuesday. ``The bond markets have weakened somewhat and a lot of legislation related to ESOPs and original discount securities has been passed,'' he said. James K. Don, president of HCA Psychiatric, has resigned and the psychiatric units will become part of HCA's network of 78 medical-surgical hospitals in the United States, Campbell said. HCA is paying back a $1.3 billion loan used to finance a $3.6 billion management-led buyout of the company earlier this year. HCA has already paid $260 million through the sales of various units.
